1159264	1159264	urn:lsid:Aphid.speciesfile.org:TaxonName:507	1159264	1159221	Pineus (Pineus) pini	Goeze. 1778. Entomologische Beyträge zu des Ritter Linné Zwölften Ausgabe des Natursystems, Weidmann Erben und Reich, Leipzig 2:352 pp	species	(Goeze, 1778)	valid		Geoffroy 1762 cites Linnaeus (1746) "Chermes pini" but uses the trinomial "Psylla lanata pini". Goeze 1778 refers to Geoffroy and gives it the name "Chermes pini". Finally, many authors credit the name to Macquart's 1819 Kermes pini, who in fact refers to both Geoffroy and Linneaus. As the Geoffroy name is suppressed (Hemming 1954), priority belongs to Chermes pini Goeze 1778 over Kermes pini Macquart 1819.	2016-04-04T06:25:00
1159265	1159265	urn:lsid:Aphid.speciesfile.org:TaxonName:511	1159264	1159221	Anisophleba pini	Koch, C.L. 1857. Die Pflanzenläuse Aphiden getreu nach dem Leben abgebildet und beschrieben, J.L. Lotzbeck, Nürnberg 9:275-335	species	Koch, 1857	junior synonym			2015-12-02T11:29:00
1159266	1159266	urn:lsid:Aphid.speciesfile.org:TaxonName:510	1159264	1159221	Chermes coniferarum	Cholodkovsky. 1889. Weiteres zur Kenntnis der Chermes-Arten. Zoologischer Anzeiger 12(305):218-223	species	Cholodkovsky, 1889	synonym		proposed as a new name should several other nominal species eventually be proven synonyms. Of those, Chermes pini Macquart 1819 has priority | He says that Chermes viridis, Ch. coccineus, Ch. laricis, Ch. obtectus, Ch. strobi, and Ch. pini, may all be one species, if so then it should be called Chermes coniferarum.   Of the species listed above Chermes pini is the oldest.  The name for the union of all of these species should have been Chermes pini.   Therefor Chermes coniferarum is an unjustified replacement name.	2015-12-02T11:29:00

Bomnii, Hamburgi et Kilonii (Hamburg and Kiel) 2:517 pp	subspecies	Fabricius, 1781	synonym	nudum; negatum	I believe this is an incorrect interpretation of Fabricius's (1781) original text, what appears to be a trinomial is simply part of the description of Aphis atriplicis. Other such apparent non-trinomials in Fabricius 1781 have not been treated as names of any sort. As such, I have recorded it as a nomen nudum. See Aphis hortensis Linnaeus 1788.	2015-12-02T11:29:00

There is no mention of how many specimens were looked at, or if he retained any of the type specimens, since it is noted that the descriptions, including the microscopic view, were based on living specimens. Soc., Vol, II., p393.  the name of the species reads Dactylosphaera forcatum [this is even a misprint.  it should be foreatum] and not forcatum, as used by Riley, Thomas, and others.  The word as used in the Transactions is evidently a misprint which originally read foveatum, with reference to the dimpled depressions on the upper side of the leaf. 1171003	1171003	urn:lsid:Aphid.speciesfile.org:TaxonName:270	1170912	1170910	Dactylosphaera	Shimer. 1867. On a new genus in Homoptera,–(Section Monomera). Proceedings of the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia 19:2-11	genus	Shimer, 1867	junior synonym		There are a variety of spellings of Daktulosphaira and Dactylosphaera, with any combination of c/k, u/y, and ae/ai. There has also been disagreement as to the type species of the genus (e.g., Russell 1975, Eastop & Hille Ris Lambers 1976). Until the matter is resolved, possibly by a ruling from the ICZN, Dactylosphaera Shimer 1867 and Daktulosphaira Shimer 1866 are here considered different names with Dactylosphaera globosum Shimer 1867 and Pemphigus vitifoliae Fitch 1851 their type species, respectively. | Shimer described Dactylosphaera and clearly placed D. globosum in it. He also listed Pemphigus vitifoliae Fitch as possibly belonging to Dactylosphaera (i.e., "Dactylosphaera ? vitifoliae"), but also suggested Viteus as a possible alternate genus name for the Fitch species. Based on this text, since D. vitifoliae, with its uncertain placement, cannot be the type species, D. globosum is here listed as type species by monotypy. | See also Dactylosphaera, incorrect spelling of Daktulosphaira Shimer 1866: http://aphid.speciesfile.org/Common/basic/Taxa.aspx?TaxonNameID=11953	2016-11-07T16:01:00

(Westwood 1877). Lichtensetin (1878), thinking the name had been published, accepted that Peritymbia would have precendence over his Rhizaphis (Planchon 1868). 1171082	1171082	urn:lsid:Aphid.speciesfile.org:TaxonName:73	1171049	1170910	Peritymbia	Westwood. 1869. New vine diseases. The Gardeners' Chronicle and Agricultural Gazette(5):109	genus	Westwood, 1869	junior synonym		Westwood first mentioned the name at a meeting of the Ashmolean society, thinking the name would be published in the proceedings. (Westwood 1877). Lichtensetin (1878), thinking the name had been published, accepted that Peritymbia would have precedence over his Rhizaphis (Planchon 1868). In fact, the Ashmolean Society only published the fact of Westwood's speech and not its content (Westwood 1867). Westwood later names the species Peritymbia vitisana (1869a) and describes it further (1869b).	2016-11-07T15:49:00
